root: ^Usually, you can list all of the smells in the procedure room by heart, but not this time. There's something foreign, sacrilegious. Alcohol. Not even the isopropyl wipes, but simple vulgar gin.
^Mateo's sitting in the chair, arms crossed just like last time, but now his eyes are hazy, no curiosity or fascination. You can't say you are happy.
^"Hi... Can you do the same thing as last time?" he pleads.

begin: ^The creams, the gels, the mask itself. That all comes naturally, as it always does. And yet, it's not enough. You need to understand what ailment you are treating.
honesty: ^"Yeah. Kind of." Mateo pauses between words, and he keeps looking somewhere into the corner, but his words are clear. "I'm just so, so tired."
^With effort, he glances at the tiny table, the contract for the session sits on top of it.

s: ^You do remember the main points by heart.

contract: ^You, the company, are not responsible for potential side effects from prior health conditions.
^You, the employee, are not allowed to share anything you hear from clients. Etc. It's smart, keeps everybody safe. Mateo read it the first time he came.
^"It's my stupid friends," Mateo starts again. This time, he doesn't watch you getting ready. His loss.

s: ^"Are they not putting the same effort?"
^You tilt your head, urging him to continue.

hospital: ^"They want to rope me into this… this scheme. And the worst part is that I'm falling for it."
^The primer. It feels stickier than usual. You're sure it's the same shipment, though.
^"The bosses – of my hospital, that is – they're not good people. They're shitty, shitty people. It's no way to run a hospital, the way they do it."
skip_1: ^He glances back at the contract again, searching for reassurance from the piece of paper.
^"I wish. But no, they skim on drugs. Then sell the excess on the market." He laughs, a tiny, gentle laugh. "And the police hardly put any effort."

^It's terrible, what he is saying. You can't imagine a place ran this way, without patient needs being put first. You worry for Mateo – must be so hard to try to work like that. And work long hours, judging by his eyes.
evidence: ^"Yeah, well, Amir and Gina, a few others – they want to get the evidence. Bring to the cops. They hope it'll make them act. And… well, it should, right?"
^The mask is on, and soon his worries will all be forgotten. He will wake up, and think about this with a clear head, and do what's right. The mask will solve it.
^Only, he fidgets in the chair. Something is wrong. Again, something is wrong.

s: ^You triple check the formula, yes, no mistakes there. Expiry dates. Equipment.

fear: ^There's only one conclusion, it is you. You're failing. Stress, it must be stress, or nervousness, or shaky hands. All can be fixed, you fixed it many times. Right now – you salvage this, and then you'll fix yourself.
^"It probably wouldn't do anything," Mateo mumbles. The treatment's still effective. You can work with it. You realise that you forgot to breathe. So stupid.

s: ^With just the tips of your fingers, you massage the mask into Mateo's face.

complacency: ^Mateo sighs. Yes, gentle pressure works. You truly hope you didn't mess it up.
^"And the hospital's still working, right? Others – they could've… right into the ground…"
^Mateo doesn't sleep, but he stops talking. He looks at you with reverence until it's over.

s: ^It's all done! Hope you're feeling better?

aftermath: ^You take a sip of lemon water from the decanter. Normally, it is for guests, but your throat feels like sandpaper.
^"I gave you my employee number last time, right?" Mateo asks.
relief: ^"Thank you. So much. This place is amazing, it clears my head, lifts my mood. No stupid fears about work."

s: ^I'm glad that I could help! I will be waiting for your next visit!
^And what about those – issues – you told me about?

confront: ^"Oh, that? I think I was just tipsy, I'm really sorry about that. I can do better than worry about the things I can't control."

s: ^You think he might be right. You don't press on.
^You think he meant it, when he said he considered his friends' plan.

remorse: ^You are about to contradict him, but from its table, the contract looks at you with scorn. You, the employee, are not to argue with the customer as not to lessen the effect of the treatment.
exit: ^You wave Mateo goodbye, and put everything back in place. You lock the door and go home early.
^Your plant must be happy to see you, but you have no time for it tonight. You go through the employee handbook a few more times, just to make sure you're ready for the next day.
